quoteText:
I suppose you would like to take them to the Casino to play roulette?
Well, excuse my speaking so plainly, but I know how addicted you are to
gambling. Though I am not your mentor, nor wish to be, at least I have
a right to require that you shall not actually _compromise_ me.
subQuotationList:
['I suppose you would like to take them to the Casino to play roulette?
Well, excuse my speaking so plainly, but I know how addicted you are to
gambling. Though I am not your mentor, nor wish to be, at least I have
a right to require that you shall not actually _compromise_ me.']
speaker: The General

quoteText: I have no money for gambling,
subQuotationList: ['I have no money for gambling,']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: But you will soon be in receipt of some,
subQuotationList: ['But you will soon be in receipt of some,']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
Let us calculate, We must translate these roubles into
thalers. Here take 100 thalers, as a round sum. The rest will be safe
in my hands.
subQuotationList: ['Let us calculate,', 'We must translate these roubles into\nthalers. Here take 100 thalers, as a round sum. The rest will be safe\nin my hands.']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
You must not be offended at what I say, You are too
touchy about these things. What I have said I have said merely as a
warning. To do so is no more than my right.
subQuotationList: ['You must not be offended at what I say,', 'You are too\ntouchy about these things. What I have said I have said merely as a\nwarning. To do so is no more than my right.']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
_Why_ do I
continue to dance attendance upon the General, instead of having left
him and his family long ago?
subQuotationList: ['_Why_ do I\ncontinue to dance attendance upon the General, instead of having left\nhim and his family long ago?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
If one is a man of self-respect, one risks abuse by so
doing, and is forced to put up with insults of every kind. Both at
Paris and on the Rhine, and even in Switzerland there are so many
Poles, with their sympathisers, the French, at these tables d h te that
one cannot get a word in edgeways if one happens only to be a Russian.
subQuotationList:
['If one is a man of self-respect,', 'one risks abuse by so
doing, and is forced to put up with insults of every kind. Both at
Paris and on the Rhine, and even in Switzerland there are so many
Poles, with their sympathisers, the French, at these tables d h te that
one cannot get a word in edgeways if one happens only to be a Russian.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Of course, one always learns _something everywhere_,
subQuotationList: ['Of course, one always learns _something everywhere_,']
speaker: Marqis De Griers

quoteText:
In Paris, too, I had a dispute with a Pole, and then
with a French officer who supported him. After that a section of the
Frenchmen present took my part. They did so as soon as I told them the
story of how once I threatened to spit into Monsignor s coffee.
subQuotationList:
['In Paris, too, I had a dispute with a Pole,', 'and then
with a French officer who supported him. After that a section of the
Frenchmen present took my part. They did so as soon as I told them the
story of how once I threatened to spit into Monsignor s coffee.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: To spit into it?
subQuotationList: ['To spit into it?']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
Just so, You must know that, on one occasion, when, for
two days, I had felt certain that at any moment I might have to depart
for Rome on business, I repaired to the Embassy of the Holy See in
Paris, to have my passport visaed. There I encountered a sacristan of
about fifty, and a man dry and cold of mien. After listening politely,
but with great reserve, to my account of myself, this sacristan asked
me to wait a little. I was in a great hurry to depart, but of course I
sat down, pulled out a copy of _L Opinion Nationale_, and fell to
reading an extraordinary piece of invective against Russia which it
happened to contain. As I was thus engaged I heard some one enter an
adjoining room and ask for Monsignor; after which I saw the sacristan
make a low bow to the visitor, and then another bow as the visitor took
his leave. I ventured to remind the good man of my own business also;
whereupon, with an expression of, if anything, increased dryness, he
again asked me to wait. Soon a third visitor arrived who, like myself,
had come on business (he was an Austrian of some sort); and as soon as
ever he had stated his errand he was conducted upstairs! This made me
very angry. I rose, approached the sacristan, and told him that, since
Monsignor was receiving callers, his lordship might just as well finish
off my affair as well. Upon this the sacristan shrunk back in
astonishment. It simply passed his understanding that any insignificant
Russian should dare to compare himself with other visitors of
Monsignor s! In a tone of the utmost effrontery, as though he were
delighted to have a chance of insulting me, he looked me up and down,
and then said: But I only cried the louder: screeched the sacristan,
again shrinking back in horror. Then, rushing to the door, he spread
out his arms as though he would rather die than let me enter.
subQuotationList:
['Just so,', 'You must know that, on one occasion, when, for
two days, I had felt certain that at any moment I might have to depart
for Rome on business, I repaired to the Embassy of the Holy See in
Paris, to have my passport visaed. There I encountered a sacristan of
about fifty, and a man dry and cold of mien. After listening politely,
but with great reserve, to my account of myself, this sacristan asked
me to wait a little. I was in a great hurry to depart, but of course I
sat down, pulled out a copy of _L Opinion Nationale_, and fell to
reading an extraordinary piece of invective against Russia which it
happened to contain. As I was thus engaged I heard some one enter an
adjoining room and ask for Monsignor; after which I saw the sacristan
make a low bow to the visitor, and then another bow as the visitor took
his leave. I ventured to remind the good man of my own business also;
whereupon, with an expression of, if anything, increased dryness, he
again asked me to wait. Soon a third visitor arrived who, like myself,
had come on business (he was an Austrian of some sort); and as soon as
ever he had stated his errand he was conducted upstairs! This made me
very angry. I rose, approached the sacristan, and told him that, since
Monsignor was receiving callers, his lordship might just as well finish
off my affair as well. Upon this the sacristan shrunk back in
astonishment. It simply passed his understanding that any insignificant
Russian should dare to compare himself with other visitors of
Monsignor s! In a tone of the utmost effrontery, as though he were
delighted to have a chance of insulting me, he looked me up and down,
and then said:', 'But I only cried the louder:', 'screeched the sacristan,
again shrinking back in horror. Then, rushing to the door, he spread
out his arms as though he would rather die than let me enter.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: But
subQuotationList: ['But']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
What really saved you was the fact that you proclaimed yourself a
heretic and a barbarian, Cela
n  tait pas si b te.
subQuotationList: ['What really saved you was the fact that you proclaimed yourself a\nheretic and a barbarian,', 'Cela\nn  tait pas si b te.']
speaker: Marqis De Griers

quoteText:
But is _that_ how Russian subjects ought to be treated? Why, when they
settle here they dare not utter even a word they are ready even to deny
the fact that they are Russians! At all events, at my hotel in Paris I
received far more attention from the company after I had told them
about the fracas with the sacristan. A fat Polish nobleman, who had
been the most offensive of all who were present at the table d h te, at
once went upstairs, while some of the Frenchmen were simply disgusted
when I told them that two years ago I had encountered a man at whom, in
1812, a French  hero  fired for the mere fun of discharging his musket.
That man was then a boy of ten and his family are still residing in
Moscow.
subQuotationList:
['But is _that_ how Russian subjects ought to be treated? Why, when they
settle here they dare not utter even a word they are ready even to deny
the fact that they are Russians! At all events, at my hotel in Paris I
received far more attention from the company after I had told them
about the fracas with the sacristan. A fat Polish nobleman, who had
been the most offensive of all who were present at the table d h te, at
once went upstairs, while some of the Frenchmen were simply disgusted
when I told them that two years ago I had encountered a man at whom, in
1812, a French  hero  fired for the mere fun of discharging his musket.
That man was then a boy of ten and his family are still residing in
Moscow.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Impossible! No French soldier would fire
at a child!
subQuotationList: ['Impossible!', 'No French soldier would fire\nat a child!']
speaker: Marqis De Griers

quoteText:
Nevertheless the incident was as I say, A very respected
ex-captain told me the story, and I myself could see the scar left on
his cheek.
subQuotationList: ['Nevertheless the incident was as I say,', 'A very respected\nex-captain told me the story, and I myself could see the scar left on\nhis cheek.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Come what may, I _must_ have money, And get it somehow I
will otherwise I shall be ruined.
subQuotationList: ['Come what may, I _must_ have money,', 'And get it somehow I\nwill otherwise I shall be ruined.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Nothing; except that two pieces of news have reached us from St.
Petersburg. In the first place, my grandmother is very ill, and
unlikely to last another couple of days. We had this from Timothy
Petrovitch himself, and he is a reliable person. Every moment we are
expecting to receive news of the end.
subQuotationList:
['Nothing; except that two pieces of news have reached us from St.
Petersburg. In the first place, my grandmother is very ill, and
unlikely to last another couple of days. We had this from Timothy
Petrovitch himself, and he is a reliable person. Every moment we are
expecting to receive news of the end.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: All of you are on the tiptoe of expectation?
subQuotationList: ['All of you are on the tiptoe of expectation?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Of course all of us, and every minute of the day. For a
year-and-a-half now we have been looking for this.
subQuotationList: ['Of course all of us, and every minute of the day. For a\nyear-and-a-half now we have been looking for this.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Looking for it?
subQuotationList: ['Looking for it?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Yes, looking for it. I am not her blood relation, you know I am merely
the General s step-daughter. Yet I am certain that the old lady has
remembered me in her will.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, looking for it. I am not her blood relation, you know I am merely\nthe General s step-daughter. Yet I am certain that the old lady has\nremembered me in her will.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Yes, I believe that you _will_ come in for a good deal,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I believe that you _will_ come in for a good deal,']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Yes, for she is fond of me. But how come you to think so?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, for she is fond of me. But how come you to think so?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: That Marquis of yours, is _he_ also familiar with your family secrets?
subQuotationList: ['That Marquis of yours,', 'is _he_ also familiar with your family secrets?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marqis De Griers'], ['Polina Alexandrovna']], [['Marqis De Griers'], ['Polina Alexandrovna']]]

quoteText: And why are you yourself so interested in them?
subQuotationList: ['And why are you yourself so interested in them?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Never mind. If I am not mistaken, the General has succeeded in
borrowing money of the Marquis.
subQuotationList: ['Never mind. If I am not mistaken, the General has succeeded in\nborrowing money of the Marquis.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: It may be so.
subQuotationList: ['It may be so.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Is it likely that the Marquis would have lent the money if he had not
known something or other about your grandmother? Did you notice, too,
that three times during luncheon, when speaking of her, he called her
 La Baboulenka ?
subQuotationList:
['Is it likely that the Marquis would have lent the money if he had not
known something or other about your grandmother? Did you notice, too,
that three times during luncheon, when speaking of her, he called her
 La Baboulenka ?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marqis De Griers'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna']]]

quoteText: What loving, friendly behaviour, to be sure!
subQuotationList: ['What loving, friendly behaviour, to be sure!']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Yes, that is true. As soon as ever he learnt that I was likely to
inherit something from her he began to pay me his addresses. I thought
you ought to know that.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, that is true. As soon as ever he learnt that I was likely to\ninherit something from her he began to pay me his addresses. I thought\nyou ought to know that.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marqis De Griers'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch']]]

quoteText:
Then he has only just begun his courting? Why, I thought he had been
doing so a long while!
subQuotationList: ['Then he has only just begun his courting? Why, I thought he had been\ndoing so a long while!']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marqis De Griers'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Marqis De Griers']]]

quoteText:
You _know_ he has not, But where on earth
did you pick up this Englishman?
subQuotationList: ['You _know_ he has not,', 'But where on earth\ndid you pick up this Englishman?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: I _knew_ you would ask about him!
subQuotationList: ['I _knew_ you would ask about him!']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
He is very shy, and susceptible. Also, he is in love with
you.
subQuotationList: ['He is very shy,', 'and susceptible. Also, he is in love with\nyou.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Yes, he _is_ in love with me,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, he _is_ in love with me,']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
And he is ten times richer than the Frenchman. In fact, what does the
Frenchman possess? To me it seems at least doubtful that he possesses
anything at all.
subQuotationList: ['And he is ten times richer than the Frenchman. In fact, what does the\nFrenchman possess? To me it seems at least doubtful that he possesses\nanything at all.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Astley'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Marqis De Griers']]]

quoteText:
Oh, no, there is no doubt about it. He does possess some ch teau or
other. Last night the General told me that for certain. _Now_ are you
satisfied?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, no, there is no doubt about it. He does possess some ch teau or\nother. Last night the General told me that for certain. _Now_ are you\nsatisfied?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Nevertheless, in your place I should marry the Englishman.
subQuotationList: ['Nevertheless, in your place I should marry the Englishman.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: And why?
subQuotationList: ['And why?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Because, though the Frenchman is the handsomer of the two, he is also
the baser; whereas the Englishman is not only a man of honour, but ten
times the wealthier of the pair.
subQuotationList: ['Because, though the Frenchman is the handsomer of the two, he is also\nthe baser; whereas the Englishman is not only a man of honour, but ten\ntimes the wealthier of the pair.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Yes? But then the Frenchman is a marquis, and the cleverer of the
two,
subQuotationList: ['Yes? But then the Frenchman is a marquis, and the cleverer of the\ntwo,']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Is that so?
subQuotationList: ['Is that so?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Yes; absolutely.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; absolutely.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
It amuses me to see you grow angry, However, inasmuch
as I allow you to indulge in these questions and conjectures, you ought
to pay me something for the privilege.
subQuotationList: ['It amuses me to see you grow angry,', 'However, inasmuch\nas I allow you to indulge in these questions and conjectures, you ought\nto pay me something for the privilege.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
I consider that I have a perfect right to put these questions to you, for the reason that I am ready to pay for them,
and also care little what becomes of me.
subQuotationList: ['I consider that I have a perfect right to put these questions to you,', 'for the reason that I am ready to pay for them,\nand also care little what becomes of me.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Last time you told me when on the Shlangenberg that at a word from me
you would be ready to jump down a thousand feet into the abyss. Some
day I may remind you of that saying, in order to see if you will be as
good as your word. Yes, you may depend upon it that I shall do so. I
hate you because I have allowed you to go to such lengths, and I also
hate you and still more because you are so necessary to me. For the
time being I want you, so I must keep you.
subQuotationList:
['Last time you told me when on the Shlangenberg that at a word from me
you would be ready to jump down a thousand feet into the abyss. Some
day I may remind you of that saying, in order to see if you will be as
good as your word. Yes, you may depend upon it that I shall do so. I
hate you because I have allowed you to go to such lengths, and I also
hate you and still more because you are so necessary to me. For the
time being I want you, so I must keep you.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch']]]

quoteText: May I ask you who is this Mlle. Blanche?
subQuotationList: ['May I ask you who is this Mlle. Blanche?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
You _know_ who she is just Mlle. Blanche. Nothing further has
transpired. Probably she will soon be Madame General that is to say, if
the rumours that Grandmamma is nearing her end should prove true. Mlle.
Blanche, with her mother and her cousin, the Marquis, know very well
that, as things now stand, we are ruined.
subQuotationList:
['You _know_ who she is just Mlle. Blanche. Nothing further has
transpired. Probably she will soon be Madame General that is to say, if
the rumours that Grandmamma is nearing her end should prove true. Mlle.
Blanche, with her mother and her cousin, the Marquis, know very well
that, as things now stand, we are ruined.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: And is the General at last in love?
subQuotationList: ['And is the General at last in love?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
That has nothing to do with it. Listen to me. Take these 700 florins,
and go and play roulette with them. Win as much for me as you can, for
I am badly in need of money.
subQuotationList: ['That has nothing to do with it. Listen to me. Take these 700 florins,\nand go and play roulette with them. Win as much for me as you can, for\nI am badly in need of money.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Do I, or do I not love her?
subQuotationList: ['Do I, or do I not love her?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
And even if you were to _win_ much I should be compromised, Of course I have no _right_ to order
your actions, but you yourself will agree that...
subQuotationList: ['And even if you were to _win_ much I should be compromised,', 'Of course I have no _right_ to order\nyour actions, but you yourself will agree that...']
speaker: The General

quoteText: Why not?
subQuotationList: ['Why not?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Because I wish to play _for myself_, That is my sole reason.
subQuotationList: ['Because I wish to play _for myself_,', 'That is my sole reason.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Then are you so certain that your roulette-playing will get us out of
our difficulties?
subQuotationList: ['Then are you so certain that your roulette-playing will get us out of\nour difficulties?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Yes,
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Possibly my certainty
about winning may seem to you ridiculous; yet, pray leave me in peace.
subQuotationList: ['Possibly my certainty\nabout winning may seem to you ridiculous; yet, pray leave me in peace.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
referringExpression: I said very seriously Yes and then added

quoteText:
I am not unwilling so to do, but in all
probability I should lose.
subQuotationList: ['I am not unwilling so to do,', 'but in all\nprobability I should lose.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Well, absurd though it be, I place great hopes on your playing of
roulette, wherefore, you ought to play as my
partner and on equal shares; wherefore, of course, you will do as I
wish.
subQuotationList:
['Well, absurd though it be, I place great hopes on your playing of
roulette,', 'wherefore, you ought to play as my
partner and on equal shares; wherefore, of course, you will do as I
wish.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
That Mlle. Blanche, Well, I have seen a good many women
like her.
subQuotationList: ['That Mlle. Blanche,', 'Well, I have seen a good many women\nlike her.']
speaker: Mr. Astley

quoteText: It is so.
subQuotationList: ['It is so.']
speaker: Mr. Astley

quoteText: Does Mlle. Polina like flowers?
subQuotationList: ['Does Mlle. Polina like flowers?']
speaker: Mr. Astley

quoteText: I really cannot say,
subQuotationList: ['I really cannot say,']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: What? You cannot say?
subQuotationList: ['What? You cannot say?']
speaker: Mr. Astley

quoteText: No; I have never noticed whether she does so or not,
subQuotationList: ['No; I have never noticed whether she does so or not,']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Hm! Then I have an idea in my mind,
subQuotationList: ['Hm! Then I have an idea in my mind,']
speaker: Mr. Astley

quoteText:
At all events, she, in her turn, has promised to give me an explanation to-night, and
to reveal to me something or another.
subQuotationList: ['At all events,', 'she, in her turn, has promised to give me an explanation to-night, and\nto reveal to me something or another.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
a man ought to go more
carefully.
subQuotationList: ['a man ought to go more\ncarefully.']
speaker: Marqis De Griers

quoteText:
though a
great many Russians go in for gambling, they are no good at the game.
subQuotationList: ['though a\ngreat many Russians go in for gambling, they are no good at the game.']
speaker: Marqis De Griers

quoteText: _I_ think that roulette was devised specially for Russians,
subQuotationList: ['_I_ think that roulette was devised specially for Russians,']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Upon what do you base your opinion?
subQuotationList: ['Upon what do you base your opinion?']
speaker: Marqis De Griers

quoteText:
Upon the fact that to the virtues and merits of the civilised
Westerner there has become historically added though this is not his
chief point a capacity for acquiring capital; whereas, not only is the
Russian incapable of acquiring capital, but also he exhausts it
wantonly and of sheer folly. None the less we Russians often need
money; wherefore, we are glad of, and greatly devoted to, a method of
acquisition like roulette whereby, in a couple of hours, one may grow
rich without doing any work. This method, I repeat, has a great
attraction for us, but since we play in wanton fashion, and without
taking any trouble, we almost invariably lose.
subQuotationList:
['Upon the fact that to the virtues and merits of the civilised
Westerner there has become historically added though this is not his
chief point a capacity for acquiring capital; whereas, not only is the
Russian incapable of acquiring capital, but also he exhausts it
wantonly and of sheer folly. None the less we Russians often need
money; wherefore, we are glad of, and greatly devoted to, a method of
acquisition like roulette whereby, in a couple of hours, one may grow
rich without doing any work. This method, I repeat, has a great
attraction for us, but since we play in wanton fashion, and without
taking any trouble, we almost invariably lose.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: To a certain extent that is true,
subQuotationList: ['To a certain extent that is true,']
speaker: Marqis De Griers

quoteText: Oh no, it is not true,
subQuotationList: ['Oh no, it is not true,']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
And you, you ought to be ashamed of yourself for traducing your
own country!
subQuotationList: ['And you,', 'you ought to be ashamed of yourself for traducing your\nown country!']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
I beg pardon, Yet it would be difficult to say which is the
worst of the two Russian ineptitude or the German method of growing
rich through honest toil.
subQuotationList: ['I beg pardon,', 'Yet it would be difficult to say which is the\nworst of the two Russian ineptitude or the German method of growing\nrich through honest toil.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: What an extraordinary idea,
subQuotationList: ['What an extraordinary idea,']
speaker: The General

quoteText: And what a _Russian_ idea!
subQuotationList: ['And what a _Russian_ idea!']
speaker: Marqis De Griers

quoteText:
I would rather live a wandering life in tents, than bow the
knee to a German idol!
subQuotationList: ['I would rather live a wandering life in tents,', 'than bow the\nknee to a German idol!']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: To _what_ idol?
subQuotationList: ['To _what_ idol?']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
To the German method of heaping up riches. I have not been here very
long, but I can tell you that what I have seen and verified makes my
Tartar blood boil. Good Lord! I wish for no virtues of that kind.
Yesterday I went for a walk of about ten versts; and, everywhere I
found that things were even as we read of them in good German
picture-books that every house has its  Vater,  who is horribly
beneficent and extraordinarily honourable. So honourable is he that it
is dreadful to have anything to do with him; and I cannot bear people
of that sort. Each such  Vater  has his family, and in the evenings
they read improving books aloud. Over their roof-trees there murmur
elms and chestnuts; the sun has sunk to his rest; a stork is roosting
on the gable; and all is beautifully poetic and touching. Do not be
angry, General. Let me tell you something that is even more touching
than that. I can remember how, of an evening, my own father, now dead,
used to sit under the lime trees in his little garden, and to read
books aloud to myself and my mother. Yes, I know how things ought to be
done. Yet every German family is bound to slavery and to submission to
its  Vater.  They work like oxen, and amass wealth like Jews. Suppose
the  Vater  has put by a certain number of g lden which he hands over
to his eldest son, in order that the said son may acquire a trade or a
small plot of land. Well, one result is to deprive the daughter of a
dowry, and so leave her among the unwedded. For the same reason, the
parents will have to sell the younger son into bondage or the ranks of
the army, in order that he may earn more towards the family capital.
Yes, such things ARE done, for I have been making inquiries on the
subject. It is all done out of sheer rectitude out of a rectitude which
is magnified to the point of the younger son believing that he has been
_rightly_ sold, and that it is simply idyllic for the victim to rejoice
when he is made over into pledge. What more have I to tell? Well,
this that matters bear just as hardly upon the eldest son. Perhaps he
has his Gretchen to whom his heart is bound; but he cannot marry her,
for the reason that he has not yet amassed sufficient g lden. So, the
pair wait on in a mood of sincere and virtuous expectation, and
smilingly deposit themselves in pawn the while. Gretchen s cheeks grow
sunken, and she begins to wither; until at last, after some twenty
years, their substance has multiplied, and sufficient g lden have been
honourably and virtuously accumulated. Then the  Vater  blesses his
forty-year-old heir and the thirty-five-year-old Gretchen with the
sunken bosom and the scarlet nose; after which he bursts, into tears,
reads the pair a lesson on morality, and dies. In turn the eldest son
becomes a virtuous  Vater,  and the old story begins again. In fifty or
sixty years  time the grandson of the original  Vater  will have
amassed a considerable sum; and that sum he will hand over to, his son,
and the latter to _his_ son, and so on for several generations; until
at length there will issue a Baron Rothschild, or a  Hoppe and
Company,  or the devil knows what! Is it not a beautiful spectacle the
spectacle of a century or two of inherited labour, patience, intellect,
rectitude, character, perseverance, and calculation, with a stork
sitting on the roof above it all? What is more; they think there can
never be anything better than this; wherefore, from _their_ point of
view they begin to judge the rest of the world, and to censure all who
are at fault that is to say, who are not exactly like themselves. Yes,
there you have it in a nutshell. For my own part, I would rather grow
fat after the Russian manner, or squander my whole substance at
roulette. I have no wish to be  Hoppe and Company  at the end of five
generations. I want the money for _myself_, for in no way do I look
upon my personality as necessary to, or meet to be given over to,
capital. I may be wrong, but there you have it. Those are _my_ views.
subQuotationList:
['To the German method of heaping up riches. I have not been here very
long, but I can tell you that what I have seen and verified makes my
Tartar blood boil. Good Lord! I wish for no virtues of that kind.
Yesterday I went for a walk of about ten versts; and, everywhere I
found that things were even as we read of them in good German
picture-books that every house has its  Vater,  who is horribly
beneficent and extraordinarily honourable. So honourable is he that it
is dreadful to have anything to do with him; and I cannot bear people
of that sort. Each such  Vater  has his family, and in the evenings
they read improving books aloud. Over their roof-trees there murmur
elms and chestnuts; the sun has sunk to his rest; a stork is roosting
on the gable; and all is beautifully poetic and touching. Do not be
angry, General. Let me tell you something that is even more touching
than that. I can remember how, of an evening, my own father, now dead,
used to sit under the lime trees in his little garden, and to read
books aloud to myself and my mother. Yes, I know how things ought to be
done. Yet every German family is bound to slavery and to submission to
its  Vater.  They work like oxen, and amass wealth like Jews. Suppose
the  Vater  has put by a certain number of g lden which he hands over
to his eldest son, in order that the said son may acquire a trade or a
small plot of land. Well, one result is to deprive the daughter of a
dowry, and so leave her among the unwedded. For the same reason, the
parents will have to sell the younger son into bondage or the ranks of
the army, in order that he may earn more towards the family capital.
Yes, such things ARE done, for I have been making inquiries on the
subject. It is all done out of sheer rectitude out of a rectitude which
is magnified to the point of the younger son believing that he has been
_rightly_ sold, and that it is simply idyllic for the victim to rejoice
when he is made over into pledge. What more have I to tell? Well,
this that matters bear just as hardly upon the eldest son. Perhaps he
has his Gretchen to whom his heart is bound; but he cannot marry her,
for the reason that he has not yet amassed sufficient g lden. So, the
pair wait on in a mood of sincere and virtuous expectation, and
smilingly deposit themselves in pawn the while. Gretchen s cheeks grow
sunken, and she begins to wither; until at last, after some twenty
years, their substance has multiplied, and sufficient g lden have been
honourably and virtuously accumulated. Then the  Vater  blesses his
forty-year-old heir and the thirty-five-year-old Gretchen with the
sunken bosom and the scarlet nose; after which he bursts, into tears,
reads the pair a lesson on morality, and dies. In turn the eldest son
becomes a virtuous  Vater,  and the old story begins again. In fifty or
sixty years  time the grandson of the original  Vater  will have
amassed a considerable sum; and that sum he will hand over to, his son,
and the latter to _his_ son, and so on for several generations; until
at length there will issue a Baron Rothschild, or a  Hoppe and
Company,  or the devil knows what! Is it not a beautiful spectacle the
spectacle of a century or two of inherited labour, patience, intellect,
rectitude, character, perseverance, and calculation, with a stork
sitting on the roof above it all? What is more; they think there can
never be anything better than this; wherefore, from _their_ point of
view they begin to judge the rest of the world, and to censure all who
are at fault that is to say, who are not exactly like themselves. Yes,
there you have it in a nutshell. For my own part, I would rather grow
fat after the Russian manner, or squander my whole substance at
roulette. I have no wish to be  Hoppe and Company  at the end of five
generations. I want the money for _myself_, for in no way do I look
upon my personality as necessary to, or meet to be given over to,
capital. I may be wrong, but there you have it. Those are _my_ views.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
How far you may be right in what you have said I do not know, but I _do_ know that you are becoming an
insufferable _far eur_ whenever you are given the least chance.
subQuotationList: ['How far you may be right in what you have said I do not know,', 'but I _do_ know that you are becoming an\ninsufferable _far eur_ whenever you are given the least chance.']
speaker: The General

quoteText: Because he is a brute,
subQuotationList: ['Because he is a brute,']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Have you noticed, too, that today he is by no means on good terms with
the General?
subQuotationList: ['Have you noticed, too, that today he is by no means on good terms with\nthe General?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Yes and I suppose you want to know why, You are aware, are you not, that the General is
mortgaged to the Marquis, with all his property? Consequently, if the
General s mother does not die, the Frenchman will become the absolute
possessor of everything which he now holds only in pledge.
subQuotationList:
['Yes and I suppose you want to know why,', 'You are aware, are you not, that the General is
mortgaged to the Marquis, with all his property? Consequently, if the
General s mother does not die, the Frenchman will become the absolute
possessor of everything which he now holds only in pledge.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alexis Ivanovitch']], [['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['The General'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['The General'], ['The General'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Marqis De Griers']]]

quoteText:
Then it is really the case that everything is mortgaged? I have heard
rumours to that effect, but was unaware how far they might be true.
subQuotationList: ['Then it is really the case that everything is mortgaged? I have heard\nrumours to that effect, but was unaware how far they might be true.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Yes, they _are_ true. What then?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, they _are_ true. What then?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Why, it will be a case of  Farewell, Mlle. Blanche, for
in such an event she would never become Madame General. Do you know, I
believe the old man is so much in love with her that he will shoot
himself if she should throw him over. At his age it is a dangerous
thing to fall in love.
subQuotationList:
['Why, it will be a case of  Farewell, Mlle. Blanche,', 'for
in such an event she would never become Madame General. Do you know, I
believe the old man is so much in love with her that he will shoot
himself if she should throw him over. At his age it is a dangerous
thing to fall in love.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Yes, something, I believe, _will_ happen to him,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, something, I believe, _will_ happen to him,']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
And what a fine thing it all is! Could anything be more
abominable than the way in which she has agreed to marry for money
alone? Not one of the decencies has been observed; the whole affair has
taken place without the least ceremony. And as for the grandmother,
what could be more comical, yet more dastardly, than the sending of
telegram after telegram to know if she is dead? What do you think of
it, Polina Alexandrovna?
subQuotationList:
['And what a fine thing it all is!', 'Could anything be more
abominable than the way in which she has agreed to marry for money
alone? Not one of the decencies has been observed; the whole affair has
taken place without the least ceremony. And as for the grandmother,
what could be more comical, yet more dastardly, than the sending of
telegram after telegram to know if she is dead? What do you think of
it, Polina Alexandrovna?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Yes, it is very horrible, Consequently, I am the more surprised that _you_ should be so
cheerful. What are _you_ so pleased about? About the fact that you have
gone and lost my money?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, it is very horrible,', 'Consequently, I am the more surprised that _you_ should be so\ncheerful. What are _you_ so pleased about? About the fact that you have\ngone and lost my money?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
What? The money that you gave me to lose? I told you I should never
win for other people least of all for you. I obeyed you simply because
you ordered me to; but you must not blame me for the result. I warned
you that no good would ever come of it. You seem much depressed at
having lost your money. Why do you need it so greatly?
subQuotationList:
['What? The money that you gave me to lose? I told you I should never
win for other people least of all for you. I obeyed you simply because
you ordered me to; but you must not blame me for the result. I warned
you that no good would ever come of it. You seem much depressed at
having lost your money. Why do you need it so greatly?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna']]]

quoteText: Why do _you_ ask me these questions?
subQuotationList: ['Why do _you_ ask me these questions?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Because you promised to explain matters to me. Listen. I am certain
that, as soon as ever I  begin to play for myself  (and I still have
120 g lden left), I shall win. You can then take of me what you
require.
subQuotationList:
['Because you promised to explain matters to me. Listen. I am certain
that, as soon as ever I  begin to play for myself  (and I still have
120 g lden left), I shall win. You can then take of me what you
require.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
You must not be angry with me, for making such a
proposal. I am so conscious of being only a nonentity in your eyes that
you need not mind accepting money from me. A gift from me could not
possibly offend you. Moreover, it was I who lost your g lden.
subQuotationList:
['You must not be angry with me,', 'for making such a
proposal. I am so conscious of being only a nonentity in your eyes that
you need not mind accepting money from me. A gift from me could not
possibly offend you. Moreover, it was I who lost your g lden.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
My affairs cannot possibly interest you, Still, if you
_do_ wish to know, I am in debt. I borrowed some money, and must pay it
back again. I have a curious, senseless idea that I am bound to win at
the gaming-tables. Why I think so I cannot tell, but I do think so, and
with some assurance. Perhaps it is because of that assurance that I now
find myself without any other resource.
subQuotationList:
['My affairs cannot possibly interest you,', 'Still, if you
_do_ wish to know, I am in debt. I borrowed some money, and must pay it
back again. I have a curious, senseless idea that I am bound to win at
the gaming-tables. Why I think so I cannot tell, but I do think so, and
with some assurance. Perhaps it is because of that assurance that I now
find myself without any other resource.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Or perhaps it is because it is so _necessary_ for you to win. It is
like a drowning man catching at a straw. You yourself will agree that,
unless he were drowning he would not mistake a straw for the trunk of a
tree.
subQuotationList:
['Or perhaps it is because it is so _necessary_ for you to win. It is
like a drowning man catching at a straw. You yourself will agree that,
unless he were drowning he would not mistake a straw for the trunk of a
tree.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
What? Do not you also hope something from it? Did you not
tell me again and again, two weeks ago, that you were certain of
winning at roulette if you played here? And did you not ask me not to
consider you a fool for doing so? Were you joking? You cannot have
been, for I remember that you spoke with a gravity which forbade the
idea of your jesting.
subQuotationList:
['What?', 'Do not you also hope something from it? Did you not
tell me again and again, two weeks ago, that you were certain of
winning at roulette if you played here? And did you not ask me not to
consider you a fool for doing so? Were you joking? You cannot have
been, for I remember that you spoke with a gravity which forbade the
idea of your jesting.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch']]]

quoteText:
True, I always felt certain that I should win.
Indeed, what you say makes me ask myself Why have my absurd, senseless
losses of today raised a doubt in my mind? Yet I am _still_ positive
that, so soon as ever I begin to play for myself, I shall infallibly
win.
subQuotationList:
['True,', 'I always felt certain that I should win.
Indeed, what you say makes me ask myself Why have my absurd, senseless
losses of today raised a doubt in my mind? Yet I am _still_ positive
that, so soon as ever I begin to play for myself, I shall infallibly
win.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: And why are you so certain?
subQuotationList: ['And why are you so certain?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
To tell the truth, I do not know. I only know that I _must_ win that
it is the one resource I have left. Yes, why do I feel so assured on
the point?
subQuotationList: ['To tell the truth, I do not know. I only know that I _must_ win that\nit is the one resource I have left. Yes, why do I feel so assured on\nthe point?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Perhaps because one cannot help winning if one is fanatically certain
of doing so.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps because one cannot help winning if one is fanatically certain\nof doing so.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Yet I dare wager that you do not think me capable of serious feeling
in the matter?
subQuotationList: ['Yet I dare wager that you do not think me capable of serious feeling\nin the matter?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
I do not care whether you are so or not, Well, since you ask me, I _do_ doubt your ability to
take anything seriously. You are capable of worrying, but not deeply.
You are too ill-regulated and unsettled a person for that. But why do
you want money? Not a single one of the reasons which you have given
can be looked upon as serious.
subQuotationList:
['I do not care whether you are so or not,', 'Well, since you ask me, I _do_ doubt your ability to
take anything seriously. You are capable of worrying, but not deeply.
You are too ill-regulated and unsettled a person for that. But why do
you want money? Not a single one of the reasons which you have given
can be looked upon as serious.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alexis Ivanovitch']], [['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch']]]

quoteText:
By the way, you say you want to pay off a debt. It
must be a large one. Is it to the Frenchman?
subQuotationList: ['By the way,', 'you say you want to pay off a debt. It\nmust be a large one. Is it to the Frenchman?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
What do you mean by asking all these questions? You are very clever
today. Surely you are not drunk?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean by asking all these questions? You are very clever\ntoday. Surely you are not drunk?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
You know that you and I stand on no ceremony, and that sometimes I put
to you very plain questions. I repeat that I am your slave and slaves
cannot be shamed or offended.
subQuotationList: ['You know that you and I stand on no ceremony, and that sometimes I put\nto you very plain questions. I repeat that I am your slave and slaves\ncannot be shamed or offended.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
You talk like a child. It is always possible to comport oneself with
dignity. If one has a quarrel it ought to elevate rather than to
degrade one.
subQuotationList: ['You talk like a child. It is always possible to comport oneself with\ndignity. If one has a quarrel it ought to elevate rather than to\ndegrade one.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
A maxim straight from the copybook! Suppose I _cannot_ comport myself
with dignity. By that I mean that, though I am a man of self-respect, I
am unable to carry off a situation properly. Do you know the reason? It
is because we Russians are too richly and multifariously gifted to be
able at once to find the proper mode of expression. It is all a
question of mode. Most of us are so bounteously endowed with intellect
as to require also a spice of genius to choose the right form of
behaviour. And genius is lacking in us for the reason that so little
genius at all exists. It belongs only to the French though a few other
Europeans have elaborated their forms so well as to be able to figure
with extreme dignity, and yet be wholly undignified persons. That is
why, with us, the mode is so all-important. The Frenchman may receive
an insult a real, a venomous insult: yet, he will not so much as frown.
But a tweaking of the nose he cannot bear, for the reason that such an
act is an infringement of the accepted, of the time-hallowed order of
decorum. That is why our good ladies are so fond of Frenchmen the
Frenchman s manners, they say, are perfect! But in my opinion there is
no such thing as a Frenchman s manners. The Frenchman is only a
bird the _coq gaulois_. At the same time, as I am not a woman, I do not
properly understand the question. Cocks may be excellent birds. If I am
wrong you must stop me. You ought to stop and correct me more often
when I am speaking to you, for I am too apt to say everything that is
in my head.
subQuotationList:
['A maxim straight from the copybook! Suppose I _cannot_ comport myself
with dignity. By that I mean that, though I am a man of self-respect, I
am unable to carry off a situation properly. Do you know the reason? It
is because we Russians are too richly and multifariously gifted to be
able at once to find the proper mode of expression. It is all a
question of mode. Most of us are so bounteously endowed with intellect
as to require also a spice of genius to choose the right form of

with extreme dignity, and yet be wholly undignified persons. That is
why, with us, the mode is so all-important. The Frenchman may receive
an insult a real, a venomous insult: yet, he will not so much as frown.
But a tweaking of the nose he cannot bear, for the reason that such an
act is an infringement of the accepted, of the time-hallowed order of
decorum. That is why our good ladies are so fond of Frenchmen the
Frenchman s manners, they say, are perfect! But in my opinion there is
no such thing as a Frenchman s manners. The Frenchman is only a
bird the _coq gaulois_. At the same time, as I am not a woman, I do not
properly understand the question. Cocks may be excellent birds. If I am
wrong you must stop me. You ought to stop and correct me more often
when I am speaking to you, for I am too apt to say everything that is
in my head.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
You see, I have lost my manners. I agree that I have none, nor yet any
dignity. I will tell you why. I set no store upon such things.
Everything in me has undergone a cheek. You know the reason. I have not
a single human thought in my head. For a long while I have been
ignorant of what is going on in the world here or in Russia. I have
been to Dresden, yet am completely in the dark as to what Dresden is
like. You know the cause of my obsession. I have no hope now, and am a
mere cipher in your eyes; wherefore, I tell you outright that wherever
I go I see only you all the rest is a matter of indifference.
subQuotationList:
['You see, I have lost my manners. I agree that I have none, nor yet any
dignity. I will tell you why. I set no store upon such things.
Everything in me has undergone a cheek. You know the reason. I have not
a single human thought in my head. For a long while I have been
ignorant of what is going on in the world here or in Russia. I have
been to Dresden, yet am completely in the dark as to what Dresden is
like. You know the cause of my obsession. I have no hope now, and am a
mere cipher in your eyes; wherefore, I tell you outright that wherever
I go I see only you all the rest is a matter of indifference.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Why or how I have come to love you I do not know. It may be that you
are not altogether fair to look upon. Do you know, I am ignorant even
as to what your face is like. In all probability, too, your heart is
not comely, and it is possible that your mind is wholly ignoble.
subQuotationList:
['Why or how I have come to love you I do not know. It may be that you
are not altogether fair to look upon. Do you know, I am ignorant even
as to what your face is like. In all probability, too, your heart is
not comely, and it is possible that your mind is wholly ignoble.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna']]]

quoteText:
And because you do not believe in my nobility of soul you think to
purchase me with money?
subQuotationList: ['And because you do not believe in my nobility of soul you think to\npurchase me with money?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: _When_ have I thought to do so?
subQuotationList: ['_When_ have I thought to do so?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
You are losing the thread of the argument. If you do not wish to
purchase me, at all events you wish to purchase my respect.
subQuotationList: ['You are losing the thread of the argument. If you do not wish to\npurchase me, at all events you wish to purchase my respect.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Not at all. I have told you that I find it difficult to explain
myself. You are hard upon me. Do not be angry at my chattering. You
know why you ought not to be angry with me that I am simply an
imbecile. However, I do not mind if you _are_ angry. Sitting in my
room, I need but to think of you, to imagine to myself the rustle of
your dress, and at once I fall almost to biting my hands. Why should
you be angry with me? Because I call myself your slave? Revel, I pray
you, in my slavery revel in it. Do you know that sometimes I could kill
you? not because I do not love you, or am jealous of you, but, because
I feel as though I could simply devour you... You are laughing!
subQuotationList:
['Not at all. I have told you that I find it difficult to explain
myself. You are hard upon me. Do not be angry at my chattering. You
know why you ought not to be angry with me that I am simply an
imbecile. However, I do not mind if you _are_ angry. Sitting in my
room, I need but to think of you, to imagine to myself the rustle of
your dress, and at once I fall almost to biting my hands. Why should
you be angry with me? Because I call myself your slave? Revel, I pray
you, in my slavery revel in it. Do you know that sometimes I could kill
you? not because I do not love you, or am jealous of you, but, because
I feel as though I could simply devour you... You are laughing!']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna']]]

quoteText:
No, I am not, But I order you, nevertheless, to be
silent.
subQuotationList: ['No, I am not,', 'But I order you, nevertheless, to be\nsilent.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: What rubbish!
subQuotationList: ['What rubbish!']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
I do not care, Also, do you know that it is not safe
for us to take walks together? Often I have a feeling that I should
like to strike you, to disfigure you, to strangle you. Are you certain
that it will never come to that? You are driving me to frenzy. Am I
afraid of a scandal, or of your anger? Why should I fear your anger? I
love without hope, and know that hereafter I shall love you a thousand
times more. If ever I should kill you I should have to kill myself too.
But I shall put off doing so as long as possible, for I wish to
continue enjoying the unbearable pain which your coldness gives me. Do
you know a very strange thing? It is that, with every day, my love for
you increases though that would seem to be almost an impossibility. Why
should I not become a fatalist? Remember how, on the third day that we
ascended the Shlangenberg, I was moved to whisper in your ear: Had you said it, I should
have leapt. Do you not believe me?
subQuotationList:
['I do not care,', 'Also, do you know that it is not safe
for us to take walks together? Often I have a feeling that I should
like to strike you, to disfigure you, to strangle you. Are you certain
that it will never come to that? You are driving me to frenzy. Am I
afraid of a scandal, or of your anger? Why should I fear your anger? I
love without hope, and know that hereafter I shall love you a thousand
times more. If ever I should kill you I should have to kill myself too.
But I shall put off doing so as long as possible, for I wish to
continue enjoying the unbearable pain which your coldness gives me. Do
you know a very strange thing? It is that, with every day, my love for
you increases though that would seem to be almost an impossibility. Why
should I not become a fatalist? Remember how, on the third day that we
ascended the Shlangenberg, I was moved to whisper in your ear:', 'Had you said it, I should
have leapt. Do you not believe me?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna', 'Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna', 'Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Polina Alexandrovna']], [['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna']]]

quoteText: What stupid rubbish!
subQuotationList: ['What stupid rubbish!']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
I care not whether it be wise or stupid, I only
know that in your presence I must speak, speak, speak. Therefore, I am
speaking. I lose all conceit when I am with you, and everything ceases
to matter.
subQuotationList:
['I care not whether it be wise or stupid,', 'I only
know that in your presence I must speak, speak, speak. Therefore, I am
speaking. I lose all conceit when I am with you, and everything ceases
to matter.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Why should I have wanted you to leap from the Shlangenberg? _That_ would have been
of no use to me.
subQuotationList: ['Why should I have wanted you to leap from the Shlangenberg?', '_That_ would have been\nof no use to me.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Splendid! I know well that you must have used the words
 of no use  in order to crush me. _I_ can see through you.  Of no use, 
did you say? Why, to give pleasure is _always_ of use; and, as for
barbarous, unlimited power even if it be only over a fly why, it is a
kind of luxury. Man is a despot by nature, and loves to torture. You,
in particular, love to do so.
subQuotationList:
['Splendid!', 'I know well that you must have used the words
 of no use  in order to crush me. _I_ can see through you.  Of no use, 
did you say? Why, to give pleasure is _always_ of use; and, as for
barbarous, unlimited power even if it be only over a fly why, it is a
kind of luxury. Man is a despot by nature, and loves to torture. You,
in particular, love to do so.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Oh no! Why so? I believe you,
subQuotationList: ['Oh no! Why so? I believe you,']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Surely you are not a coward?
subQuotationList: ['Surely you are not a coward?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
I do not know, Perhaps I am, but I do not know. I have
long given up thinking about such things.
subQuotationList: ['I do not know,', 'Perhaps I am, but I do not know. I have\nlong given up thinking about such things.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: If I said to you,  Kill that man,  would you kill him?
subQuotationList: ['If I said to you,  Kill that man,  would you kill him?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Whom?
subQuotationList: ['Whom?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Whomsoever I wish?
subQuotationList: ['Whomsoever I wish?']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: The Frenchman?
subQuotationList: ['The Frenchman?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Do not ask me questions; return me answers. I repeat, whomsoever I
wish? I desire to see if you were speaking seriously just now.
subQuotationList: ['Do not ask me questions; return me answers. I repeat, whomsoever I\nwish? I desire to see if you were speaking seriously just now.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Do _you_, rather, tell me, what is going on here? Why do you
seem half-afraid of me? I can see for myself what is wrong. You are the
step-daughter of a ruined and insensate man who is smitten with love
for this devil of a Blanche. And there is this Frenchman, too, with his
mysterious influence over you. Yet, you actually ask me such a
question! If you do not tell me how things stand, I shall have to put
in my oar and do something. Are you ashamed to be frank with me? Are
you shy of me?
subQuotationList:
['Do _you_, rather, tell me,', 'what is going on here? Why do you
seem half-afraid of me? I can see for myself what is wrong. You are the
step-daughter of a ruined and insensate man who is smitten with love
for this devil of a Blanche. And there is this Frenchman, too, with his
mysterious influence over you. Yet, you actually ask me such a
question! If you do not tell me how things stand, I shall have to put
in my oar and do something. Are you ashamed to be frank with me? Are
you shy of me?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Polina Alexandrovna']], [['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna']]]

quoteText:
I am not going to talk to you on that subject. I have asked you a
question, and am waiting for an answer.
subQuotationList: ['I am not going to talk to you on that subject. I have asked you a\nquestion, and am waiting for an answer.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Well, then I will kill whomsoever you wish, But are you
_really_ going to bid me do such deeds?
subQuotationList: ['Well, then I will kill whomsoever you wish,', 'But are you\n_really_ going to bid me do such deeds?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Why should you think that I am going to let you off? I shall bid you
do it, or else renounce me. Could you ever do the latter? No, you know
that you couldn t. You would first kill whom I had bidden you, and then
kill _me_ for having dared to send you away!
subQuotationList:
['Why should you think that I am going to let you off? I shall bid you
do it, or else renounce me. Could you ever do the latter? No, you know
that you couldn t. You would first kill whom I had bidden you, and then
kill _me_ for having dared to send you away!']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch']]]

quoteText:
Do you see that fat Baroness? It is the Baroness
Burmergelm. She arrived three days ago. Just look at her husband that
tall, wizened Prussian there, with the stick in his hand. Do you
remember how he stared at us the other day? Well, go to the Baroness,
take off your hat to her, and say something in French.
subQuotationList:
['Do you see that fat Baroness?', 'It is the Baroness
Burmergelm. She arrived three days ago. Just look at her husband that
tall, wizened Prussian there, with the stick in his hand. Do you
remember how he stared at us the other day? Well, go to the Baroness,
take off your hat to her, and say something in French.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
Because you have sworn that you would leap from the Shlangenberg for
my sake, and that you would kill any one whom I might bid you kill.
Well, instead of such murders and tragedies, I wish only for a good
laugh. Go without answering me, and let me see the Baron give you a
sound thrashing with his stick.
subQuotationList:
['Because you have sworn that you would leap from the Shlangenberg for
my sake, and that you would kill any one whom I might bid you kill.
Well, instead of such murders and tragedies, I wish only for a good
laugh. Go without answering me, and let me see the Baron give you a
sound thrashing with his stick.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Then you throw me out a challenge? you think that I will not do it?
subQuotationList: ['Then you throw me out a challenge? you think that I will not do it?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Yes, I do challenge you. Go, for such is my will.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I do challenge you. Go, for such is my will.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
Then I _will_ go, however mad be your fancy. Only, look here: shall
you not be doing the General a great disservice, as well as, through
him, a great disservice to yourself? It is not about myself I am
worrying it is about you and the General. Why, for a mere fancy, should
I go and insult a woman?
subQuotationList:
['Then I _will_ go, however mad be your fancy. Only, look here: shall
you not be doing the General a great disservice, as well as, through
him, a great disservice to yourself? It is not about myself I am
worrying it is about you and the General. Why, for a mere fancy, should
I go and insult a woman?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['The General'], ['The General'], ['Polina Alexandrovna'], ['The General']]]

quoteText:
Ah! Then I can see that you are only a trifler, Your eyes are swimming with blood but only because you
have drunk a little too much at luncheon. Do I not know that what I
have asked you to do is foolish and wrong, and that the General will be
angry about it? But I want to have a good laugh, all the same. I want
that, and nothing else. Why should you insult a woman, indeed? Well,
you will be given a sound thrashing for so doing.
subQuotationList:
['Ah! Then I can see that you are only a trifler,', 'Your eyes are swimming with blood but only because you
have drunk a little too much at luncheon. Do I not know that what I
have asked you to do is foolish and wrong, and that the General will be

that, and nothing else. Why should you insult a woman, indeed? Well,
you will be given a sound thrashing for so doing.']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText: Madame la Baronne, j ai l honneur d  tre votre esclave.
subQuotationList: ['Madame la Baronne,', 'j ai l honneur d  tre votre esclave.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Hein!
subQuotationList: ['Hein!']
speaker: The Baron
referringExpression: ejaculated or rather growled the Baron

quoteText: Hein!
subQuotationList: ['Hein!']
speaker: The Baron

quoteText: Ja wohl!
subQuotationList: ['Ja wohl!']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Sind Sie rasend?
subQuotationList: ['Sind Sie rasend?']
speaker: The Baron

quoteText: Ja wo-o-ohl!
subQuotationList: ['Ja wo-o-ohl!']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: I have perpetrated the the piece of idiocy,
subQuotationList: ['I have perpetrated the the piece of idiocy,']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: Have you? Then you can take the consequences,
subQuotationList: ['Have you? Then you can take the consequences,']
speaker: Polina Alexandrovna

quoteText:
My good sir, may I ask you what this is that you
have gone and done?
subQuotationList: ['My good sir,', 'may I ask you what this is that you\nhave gone and done?']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
I should be glad, if we could come straight to the point.
Probably you are referring to my encounter of today with a German?
subQuotationList: ['I should be glad,', 'if we could come straight to the point.\nProbably you are referring to my encounter of today with a German?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
With a German? Why, the German was the Baron Burmergelm a most
important personage! I hear that you have been rude both to him and to
the Baroness?
subQuotationList: ['With a German? Why, the German was the Baron Burmergelm a most\nimportant personage! I hear that you have been rude both to him and to\nthe Baroness?']
speaker: The General

quoteText: No, I have not.
subQuotationList: ['No, I have not.']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText: But I understand that you simply terrified them, my good sir?
subQuotationList: ['But I understand that you simply terrified them, my good sir?']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
Not in the least, You must know that when I was in Berlin
I frequently used to hear the Berliners repeat, and repellently
prolong, a certain phrase namely, and, happening to meet
this couple in the carriage-drive, I found, for some reason or another,
that this phrase suddenly recurred to my memory, and exercised a
rousing effect upon my spirits. Moreover, on the three previous
occasions that I have met the Baroness she has walked towards me as
though I were a worm which could easily be crushed with the foot. Not
unnaturally, I too possess a measure of self-respect; wherefore, on
_this_ occasion I took off my hat, and said politely (yes, I assure you
it was said politely): Then the Baron turned round, and said whereupon I felt moved
to ejaculate in answer Twice I shouted it at him the first
time in an ordinary tone, and the second time with the greatest
prolonging of the words of which I was capable. That is all.
subQuotationList:
['Not in the least,', 'You must know that when I was in Berlin
I frequently used to hear the Berliners repeat, and repellently
prolong, a certain phrase namely,', 'and, happening to meet

to ejaculate in answer', 'Twice I shouted it at him the first
time in an ordinary tone, and the second time with the greatest

speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The General']], [['Baroness Burmergelm'], ['Baroness Burmergelm'], ['The General']], [['The Baron']], [], [['The Baron']]]

quoteText: You are only making fun of me!
subQuotationList: ['You are only making fun of me!']
speaker: The General

quoteText:
Do not think _that_, It was not so at all. I grant you
that my behaviour was bad I fully confess that it was so, and make no
secret of the fact. I would even go so far as to grant you that my
behaviour might well be called stupid and indecent tomfoolery; but,
_more_ than that it was not. Also, let me tell you that I am very sorry
for my conduct. Yet there is one circumstance which, in my eyes, almost
absolves me from regret in the matter. Of late that is to say, for the
last two or three weeks I have been feeling not at all well. That is to
say, I have been in a sick, nervous, irritable, fanciful condition, so
that I have periodically lost control over myself. For instance, on
more than one occasion I have tried to pick a quarrel even with
Monsieur le Marquise here; and, under the circumstances, he had no
choice but to answer me. In short, I have recently been showing signs
of ill-health. Whether the Baroness Burmergelm will take this
circumstance into consideration when I come to beg her pardon (for I
_do_ intend to make her amends) I do not know; but I doubt if she will,
and the less so since, so far as I know, the circumstance is one which,
of late, has begun to be abused in the legal world, in that advocates
in criminal cases have taken to justifying their clients on the ground
that, at the moment of the crime, they (the clients) were unconscious
of what they were doing that, in short, they were out of health.  My
client committed the murder that is true; but he has no recollection of
having committed it.  And doctors actually support these advocates by
affirming that there really is such a malady that there really _can_
arise temporary delusions which make a man remember nothing of a given
deed, or only a half or a quarter of it! But the Baron and Baroness are
members of an older generation, as well as Prussian Junkers and
landowners. To them such a process in the medico-judicial world will be
unknown, and therefore, they are the more unlikely to accept any such
explanation. What is _your_ opinion about it, General?
subQuotationList:
['Do not think _that_,', 'It was not so at all. I grant you
that my behaviour was bad I fully confess that it was so, and make no
secret of the fact. I would even go so far as to grant you that my
behaviour might well be called stupid and indecent tomfoolery; but,
_more_ than that it was not. Also, let me tell you that I am very sorry
for my conduct. Yet there is one circumstance which, in my eyes, almost

speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The General'], ['The General'], ['The General'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Marqis De Griers'], ['Baroness Burmergelm'], ['Baroness Burmergelm'], ['Baroness Burmergelm'], ['Baroness Burmergelm'], ['The General'], ['The General']]]

quoteText:
Enough, sir! Enough, I
say! Once and for all I must endeavour to rid myself of you and your
impertinence. To justify yourself in the eyes of the Baron and Baroness
will be impossible. Any intercourse with you, even though it be
confined to a begging of their pardons, they would look upon as a
degradation. I may tell you that, on learning that you formed part of
my household, the Baron approached me in the Casino, and demanded of me
additional satisfaction. Do you understand, then, what it is that you
have entailed upon me upon _me_, my good sir? You have entailed upon me
the fact of my being forced to sue humbly to the Baron, and to give him
my word of honour that this very day you shall cease to belong to my
establishment!
subQuotationList:
['Enough, sir!', 'Enough, I
say! Once and for all I must endeavour to rid myself of you and your
impertinence. To justify yourself in the eyes of the Baron and Baroness
will be impossible. Any intercourse with you, even though it be
confined to a begging of their pardons, they would look upon as a
degradation. I may tell you that, on learning that you formed part of
my household, the Baron approached me in the Casino, and demanded of me
additional satisfaction. Do you understand, then, what it is that you
have entailed upon me upon _me_, my good sir? You have entailed upon me
the fact of my being forced to sue humbly to the Baron, and to give him
my word of honour that this very day you shall cease to belong to my
establishment!']
speaker: The General
mentionTextsList: [['sir'], ['you', 'your', 'the Baron and Baroness', 'you', 'their', 'they', 'you', 'you', 'the Baron', 'you', 'you', 'my good sir', 'You', 'the Baron', 'him', 'you']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alexis Ivanovitch']], [['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Baroness Burmergelm', 'The Baron'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Baroness Burmergelm', 'The Baron'], ['Baroness Burmergelm', 'The Baron'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['The Baron'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['The Baron'], ['The Baron'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch']]]

quoteText:
Excuse me, General, but did he make an express point
of it that I should  cease to belong to your establishment,  as you
call it?
subQuotationList: ['Excuse me, General,', 'but did he make an express point\nof it that I should  cease to belong to your establishment,  as you\ncall it?']
speaker: Alexis Ivanovitch

quoteText:
No; I, of my own initiative, thought that I ought to afford him that
satisfaction; and, with it he was satisfied. So we must part, good sir.
It is my duty to hand over to you forty g lden, three florins, as per
the accompanying statement. Here is the money, and here the account,
which you are at liberty to verify. Farewell. From henceforth we are
strangers. From you I have never had anything but trouble and
unpleasantness. I am about to call the landlord, and explain to him
that from tomorrow onwards I shall no longer be responsible for your
hotel expenses. Also I have the honour to remain your obedient
servant.
subQuotationList:
['No; I, of my own initiative, thought that I ought to afford him that
satisfaction; and, with it he was satisfied. So we must part, good sir.
It is my duty to hand over to you forty g lden, three florins, as per
the accompanying statement. Here is the money, and here the account,
which you are at liberty to verify. Farewell. From henceforth we are
strangers. From you I have never had anything but trouble and
unpleasantness. I am about to call the landlord, and explain to him
that from tomorrow onwards I shall no longer be responsible for your
hotel expenses. Also I have the honour to remain your obedient
servant.']
speaker: The General
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Baron'], ['The Baron'], ['The General', 'Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch', 'The General'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['The Baron'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch'], ['Alexis Ivanovitch']]]

quoteText:
The matter cannot end here. I regret very much that you should have
been put to unpleasantness at the Baron s hands; but, the fault (pardon
me) is your own. How came you to answer for me to the Baron? And what
did you mean by saying that I formed part of your household? I am
merely your family tutor not a son of yours, nor yet your ward, nor a
person of any kind for whose acts you need be responsible. I am a
judicially competent person, a man of twenty-five years of age, a
university graduate, a gentleman, and, until I met yourself, a complete
stranger to you. Only my boundless respect for your merits restrains me
from demanding satisfaction at your hands, as well as a further
explanation as to the reasons which have led you to take it upon
yourself to answer for my conduct.
subQuotationList:
['The matter cannot end here. I regret very much that you should have
been put to unpleasantness at the Baron s hands; but, the fault (pardon
